title: Problem Introduction
content:
**Erdős Problem #813: Triangles in Every 7-Vertex Set**

Let h(n) be minimal such that every graph on n vertices where every 7-vertex set contains a triangle must contain a clique of size h(n).

**Question:** Do constants c₁, c₂ > 0 exist such that n^{1/3+c₁} ≪ h(n) ≪ n^{1/2-c₂}?

**Status:** OPEN with significant progress.
mathContext: This is a Ramsey-type problem connecting local density (triangles in small sets) to global structure (clique size).

title: Triangle and Local Condition
content:
**HasTriangle G v₁ v₂ v₃:**

A triangle K₃ exists on vertices v₁, v₂, v₃ if all three pairs are adjacent.

**Every7SetHasTriangle G:**

Every subset of 7 vertices contains at least one triangle. This is the key local density condition.
mathContext: The number 7 is significant: R(3,3) = 6, so every 6-vertex set has a triangle or independent triple. Requiring triangle in every 7-set is stronger.

title: Cliques
content:
**IsClique G S:**

S is a clique if every pair of distinct vertices in S is adjacent.

**cliqueNumber G:**

The maximum size of a clique in G. This is the global structure we want to understand.
mathContext: The clique number ω(G) is a fundamental graph invariant. Finding large cliques is computationally hard (NP-complete).

title: The Function h(n)
content:
**h(n):**

The minimum clique size guaranteed in any graph on n vertices where every 7-vertex set contains a triangle.

**SatisfiesH n h:**

Every such graph has a clique of size at least h.
mathContext: This is a minimum over a class of graphs, then maximum over all graphs in that class - a classic extremal problem formulation.

title: Erdős-Hajnal Bounds
content:
**erdos_hajnal_lower_bound:**

h(n) ≫ n^{1/3} - there exist graphs with every 7-set having a triangle but clique number only ~n^{1/3}.

**erdos_hajnal_upper_bound:**

h(n) ≪ n^{1/2} - every such graph has clique at least ~n^{1/2}.

**Combined:** n^{1/3} ≪ h(n) ≪ n^{1/2}
mathContext: The exponent gap [1/3, 1/2] was the original state of knowledge. Closing this gap is the main challenge.

title: Bucić-Sudakov Improvement (2023)
content:
**bucic_sudakov_lower_bound:**

h(n) ≫ n^{5/12-o(1)}

This improves the lower bound exponent from 1/3 ≈ 0.333 to 5/12 ≈ 0.417.

**five_twelfths_better:** 5/12 > 1/3

**exponent_gap:** 1/2 - 5/12 = 1/12
mathContext: Bucić and Sudakov (2023) used sophisticated algebraic and probabilistic methods. The gap is now [5/12, 1/2].

title: The Main Conjecture
content:
**ErdosConjecture813:**

Do constants c₁, c₂ > 0 exist such that:
- h(n) ≥ c₁ · n^{1/3+c₁} (improved lower)
- h(n) ≤ c₂ · n^{1/2-c₂} (improved upper)

This asks whether the exponents can be strictly improved from 1/3 and 1/2.
mathContext: The conjecture remains open. Even small improvements in the exponents would be significant.

title: Why 7?
content:
**why_seven:**

The number 7 is significant because R(3,3) = 6.

In any 6-vertex graph, there's either a triangle or an independent set of 3 vertices. Requiring a triangle in every 7-set forces more structure than just having dense graphs.
mathContext: R(3,3) = 6 is the first non-trivial Ramsey number. The constraint "triangle in every 7-set" goes just beyond this threshold.

title: Proof Techniques
content:
**Lower bound (probabilistic):** Random constructions show graphs exist with small cliques but many local triangles.

**Upper bound (Turán-type):** High local density forces many edges, which by Turán-type arguments forces large cliques.

**5/12 improvement (algebraic):** Bucić-Sudakov use polynomial/algebraic graph constructions.
mathContext: The interplay of probabilistic and algebraic methods is characteristic of modern extremal combinatorics.

title: Summary
content:
**erdos_813_summary:**

- h(n) = minimum clique size when every 7-set has a triangle
- Known: n^{1/3} ≪ h(n) ≪ n^{1/2} (Erdős-Hajnal)
- Improved: h(n) ≫ n^{5/12-o(1)} (Bucić-Sudakov 2023)
- Open: Can exponents 1/3+ε and 1/2-ε be achieved?

**Status:** OPEN with significant progress.
mathContext: The problem illustrates how local density conditions constrain global structure, a central theme in extremal graph theory.
